Title: Linking forum posts -compilers-01-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.threadtitle: What are denotational and axiomatic semantics good for?
Input.posts:
Lecture 13-01 mentions two other semantics (denotational and axiomatic), and states there are not useful for describing the evaluation of the program. It is also briefly mentiones that axiomatic semantics is used for program verification. Why both semantics are not good for the task of describing the evaluation of the program, and what are typical applications?
Upvotes:
3
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Both other kinds of semantics can be used to describe program evaluation, but they can also do more and so are heavier weight mechanisms if all you want to do is describe how things execute. Operational semantics is minimalistic in the sense that it only describes how programs execute and nothing more. The simplest form of denotational semantics maps programs into a mathematical domain of functions that model the input/output behavior of a program. Because the denotations of programs are required to be functions, the designer of the denotational semantics has to *prove* that they are indeed functions (or else the whole construction makes no sense). In fact, one has to prove that the functions have some special properties that guarantees they are computable functions. In axiomatic semantics one designs a logic for reasoning about programs in the particular language. This logic ought to have certain properties that all well-formed logics have, so again, there is more work to do than simply giving the rules.

This logic ought to have certain properties that all well-formed logics have, so again, there is more work to do than simply giving the rules.
Upvotes:
5

Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.threadtitle: Releasing lecture videos and assignments 1 weeks in advance?
Input.posts:
Hi, To work around vacation plans, is it possible for you to release material and assignments a week in advance? Some of us travel to locations that do not have net connectivity. For example, you can release Week 1 and Week 2 work now. Next week you can release Week 3 material and so on. This was done for the POSA course last year on Coursera and it worked out pretty well. Thanks!
Upvotes:
9
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
It's a good idea, but I'd rather not do it for a couple of reasons. First, there is already a self-paced version of this class on Coursera with all the same material. If you want to get ahead you can go there and get all the lectures and assignments (but note that there seems to be an issue with actually accessing the self-paced course at the moment; looks like Coursera doesn't like to have two versions of a class available simultaneously. I hope this will be fixed shortly.). Second, the advantage of this offering over the self-paced version is that there are lots of students doing it together who can talk to each other; loosening the schedule will only detract from that for most people.

If you want to get ahead you can go there and get all the lectures and assignments (but note that there seems to be an issue with actually accessing the self-paced course at the moment; looks like Coursera doesn't like to have two versions of a class available simultaneously. I hope this will be fixed shortly.). Second, the advantage of this offering over the self-paced version is that there are lots of students doing it together who can talk to each other; loosening the schedule will only detract from that for most people.
